ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: virtual seminar (group discussions, one-on-one session), virtual lectures
A lot of the class involved shooting pictures on our own time.
We also had individual meeting about our work.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: how to handle a DSLR camera (light, shutter speed, aperture); working with camera raw files; how to fix lighting using adobe bridge; color corrections and some basic tools on photoshop, how to be observant and meticulous viewing other artists artworks
I learned how to use a DSLR camera and edit photos in Camera Raw and PS
Learned the basics of manual photography with DSLR cameras.
I learned about the process of taking photographs and preparing them using photoshop. We discussed the ethics of photography as well.

I learned sooooo much from this course and I would recommend it to any student, Art major or not. I think Professor Partin can de-mystify photography and make it an accessible medium for anybody. I already had a little bit of experience with photography, and I learned just as much about the practice (as well as editing/organization techniques in Adobe Bridge and Photoshop) than I think I would have had I been starting from scratch.
I learned so much about photography and my progress was visible at the end! Very grateful I took it!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength: Ted is both an amazing person and a professor. Low workload. Low stress. Fun assignments (got to go out and take photos!).

Weakness: I wish I could print more photos in the lab if we had this class in person, but because of covid that was limiting. Still we get to print a book for our final project so we didn't miss out on all.
This was a great course, and I learned a lot about both photography and photography history.
A strength of this class was its structure, or lack thereof. Prof. Partin allowed us to find our own path through photography and explore the world through the lens of a camera.

I think this course did a really good job of being administered remotely. Even though it was a shame we were not able to print our images and critique each other in person, I really like the book project. I cant think of anything that would make it better; in my opinion it was an excellent course.
This was one of the best classes I have taken at Yale!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this class was very accommodating for remote learning. If anything, it benefited from it because we were all photographing different places. I think Professor Partin was very accommodating of our difficulties.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
YES, TAKE IT! Though, you need to provide yourself a DSLR camera and a hard drive (which honestly isn't that difficult). If you don't own a DSLR, try reaching out to other people who can lend you for a semester or consider getting a used camera online!

Ted is amazing. He is so passionate about photography and really engaging during class. I worried that taking an art class in a virtual space will limit my learning, but I was wrong. He gave us plenty of individual attention (had one-on-one sessions) where we got to ask specific questions we had about our project, and it was truly helpful. Lectures about technical aspects of photographing and editing are really useful. The guest lecture was very fun -- definitely needed that lecture in midst of all the zoom fatigue!

This was my first art class taken at Yale, and during the first few weeks, I felt a little bit stuck. I felt like I needed more guidance and scope when Ted told us to "go out on an adventure and take pictures of anything you want". I felt impatient that my photos will seem random and won't have a cohesive theme. I tried to take photos every week at least once or twice (about 100-150 photos per week on average), and slowly I started to see a pattern in things I like to photograph. So do be afraid to take this class even if you have no art background. :))
I recommend this class to anyone who wants to learn more about photography, whether they're an expert or a beginner.
Would recommend this course! A great introduction to the world of photography
Yes I would. It is a great break from the rigid syllabi of other classes and it made me think about creating art in a different way.

Yes. I would recommend this course to any student genuinely interested in art and/or photography. The workload is fairly heavy but if you are interested in it, its very rewarding and totally worth it.
YES!!!! If you want to explore photography please do!
